name: Gwynn ap Nudd

attributes.attribute: name means Gwynn, son of Nudd
father was king of a Hades-like Otherworld called Annwn
surrounded by his beautiful host playing Fairy Music
on whom Shakespeare based the character of Cordelia in King Lear
Alternative names used of Gwyn ap Nudd are Herne the Hunter, the frightening figure who skulks around Windsor Forest in England; and Gabriel, known best for his vicious fairy hounds

sources: Evans-Wentz, W. Y. The Fairy-Faith in Celtic Countries. Gerrards Cross: Colin Smythe Humanities Press, 1911, 152 ff.
Lonigan, Paul R. *The Druids: Priests of the Ancient Celts.* Contributions to the Study of Religion, no. 45. Westport, Conn.: Greenwood Press, 1996, 169.
Spence, Lewis. The Minor Traditions of British Mythology. (New York: Benjamin Blom, Inc., 1972), 109.
Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: Gwynn ap Nudd was a Welsh hero, also known as Gwyn ap Nudd, Herne, Herne the Hunter, and Gabriel. He was the king of Fairyland and was referred to as the "White One, son of the Dark." His dwelling place was believed to be under the Glastonbury Tor, the most significant feature in southwestern England. He ruled over the Tylwyth Teg, a group of tiny and beautiful people who wore blue and danced throughout the night similar to Irish Fairies. His favorite celebration was Beltane, the start of spring, during which he led the Wild Hunt to terrorize the living. He was named Gwynn, son of Nudd, and his father was the king of Annwn, an Otherworld similar to Hades. Gwynn could appear at any moment, accompanied by his enchanting host who played Fairy Music. His queen was Creiddylad, daughter of Lludd, who was the basis for Shakespeare's Cordelia in King Lear. Alternative names used for Gwyn ap Nudd included Herne the Hunter, a frightening figure who roamed Windsor Forest in England, and Gabriel, famous for his ferocious fairy hounds.
